column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column7: During the suspension of operations, we completed a safety review across all activities at Brucejack to identify significant hazards and corresponding critical controls. This review has helped Newcrest to establish additional verification mechanisms to monitor those essential controls. The outcome of this work has been shared across NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs global operations to help prevent fatalities in the future and to ensure consistent best safety practices. The New South Wales Resources Regulator continues investigating two safety incidents at Cadia. These are in response to a severe injury that occurred to a team member from one of CadiaÃ¢ÂÂs contracting partners in June 2023 and a separate incident resulting in severe injuries to a teamÃÂ member that occurred in October 2021. Newcrest remains committed to learning from these devastating incidents to ensure that safety remains at the forefront of everyÃÂ activity across the business to help prevent fatalities and life-changing injuries in the future.

column13: Scheduled system verifications were introduced for all sites in FY23 to ensure proof of every critical control relevant to the site risk profile at least once during the financial year. Higher risk significant hazard essential controls were also scheduled more frequently.

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: Red Chris was awarded the BC Mine Safety Award for best injury performance for all mines in BC with over 1m work hours and the Mine Safety Technology Award for Core Shack design and work completed for ergonomic injury reduction. Additionally, the Red Chris Emergency Response Team won several awards at the 65th Annual Mine Rescue Competition.

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: When our Red Chris environmental team collect samples in winter, they can be on ice up to 300 metres from shore. Ice Rescue Training is designed to equip our team with the required safety skills to manage any unexpected events that could arise on the ice. Including classroom and field training on Kluachon Lake in Iskut, participants learn about the different types of ice, the best rescue systems and methods, and the importance of staying calm in an emergency.
column20: Ice Rescue Training, Classroom and Field Training, Kluachon Lake in Iskut
